nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed modern applied microeconomics by promoting research designs that identify causal effects using natural experiments and formalizing the interpretation of instrumental variable estimates
Design-based empirical practice emphasizes clear research designs that exploit plausibly as-good-as-random variation and construct appropriate comparison groups to identify causal effects

The local average treatment effect (LATE) theorem formalizes that with a valid instrument the IV estimand identifies the average treatment effect for compliers under assumptions of random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance

Natural experiments and quasi-experiments (including randomized controlled trials, difference-in-differences, regression discontinuity, shift-share instruments) are central sources of credible treatment variation in labor economics research

A design-based focus draws a distinction between internal validity (credible identification in the study population) and external validity (generalizability), highlighting treatment effect heterogeneity and limits of extrapolation
Empirical applications by the laureates provided surprising and influential substantive findings that challenged prior consensus in labor economics
Difference-in-differences and carefully constructed control groups can isolate treatment effects from time-varying confounders when treatment timing or location is plausibly exogenous

Researchers must make identifying assumptions explicit (e.g., parallel trends for diff-in-diff, exclusion and monotonicity for IV) and subject them to institutional validation and falsification checks
Researchers often collect bespoke or linked administrative data tailored to the research design rather than relying only on standard public microdata

LATE clarifies interpretation of IV: the IV estimate is a weighted average treatment effect for compliers, not the population average, and requires distinguishing statistical random assignment from substantive exclusion and monotonicity assumptions
Because IV/LATE identifies effects for compliers and effects can vary across subgroups and designs, generalizing IV estimates requires either structural modeling or additional credible variation

Representative empirical studies: Card (1990) Mariel boatlift using city comparisons; Card and Krueger (1994) NJ-Penn fast-food diff-in-diff; Angrist and Krueger (1991) quarter-of-birth IV for schooling returns; Angrist (1990) draft-lottery IV for military service; Imbens et al. (2001) lottery winners for unearned income; Card and Hyslop (2005) experimental earnings subsidy with structural modeling

Limitations of the design-based approach include narrow sources of variation that may identify only local effects, potential violations of exclusion or monotonicity, and the need for external validity analyses

Key substantive results from the laureates' empirical work: the Mariel and related studies find limited adverse effects of immigration on native employment and wages in many settings; the Card and Krueger minimum wage study found no employment decline in fast-food after a large minimum wage increase; IV studies find nonzero positive returns to schooling and substantial heterogeneous effects depending on margin and instrument; draft-lottery IV showed negative earnings effects of military service for compliers

Together, these methodological clarifications and empirical findings reshaped empirical labor economics by prioritizing transparent research design, promoting natural-experiment methods, and formalizing the interpretation and limitations of IV-based causal claims
